articles.headline: Small U.S. Farms Find Profit in Tourism
articles.snippet: To survive, small farmers in America are increasingly turning to nonfarm activities, like operating bed-and-breakfasts.
articles.abstract: To survive, small farmers in America are increasingly turning to nonfarm activities, like operating bed-and-breakfasts.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MARGARITA, Calif. — For all the talk about sustainable agriculture, most small farms are not self-sustaining in a very basic sense: they can’t make ends meet financially without relying on income from jobs off the farm.

articles.headline: Ex-N.S.A. Aide Gains Plea Deal in Leak Case; Setback to U.S.
articles.snippet: A former spy agency employee agreed to plead guilty to a minor charge in a highly publicized leak prosecution, undercutting U.S. efforts to stem leaks of classified data to the press.
articles.abstract: A former spy agency employee agreed to plead guilty to a minor charge in a highly publicized leak prosecution, undercutting U.S. efforts to stem leaks of classified data to the press.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former spy agency employee agreed late Thursday to plead guilty to a minor charge in a highly publicized leak prosecution, undercutting the Obama administration’s unusual campaign to prosecute government officials who disclose classified information to the press.

articles.headline: I.B.M. Researchers Create High-Speed Graphene Circuits
articles.snippet: The advance, reported in the journal Science, may have applications that include future smartphone and telephone displays.
articles.abstract: The advance, reported in the journal Science, may have applications that include future smartphone and telephone displays.
articles.lead_paragraph: I.B.M. researchers said Thursday that they had designed high-speed circuits from graphene, an ultra-thin material that has a host of promising applications, from high-bandwidth communication to a new generation of low-cost smartphone and television displays.

articles.headline: Egypt’s Economy Slows to a Crawl; Revolt Is Tested
articles.snippet: In a region where economic woes enraged an entire generation, whether and how Egypt can fix its broken finances will be a key factor in determining the revolution’s success.
articles.abstract: In a region where economic woes enraged an entire generation, whether and how Egypt can fix its broken finances will be a key factor in determining the revolution’s success.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s economy, whose inequities and lack of opportunities helped topple a government, has now ground to a virtual halt, further wounded by the revolution itself.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Dina Salah Amer

articles.headline: Gingrich’s Future in Question After Aides Quit en Masse
articles.snippet: Newt Gingrich’s campaign imploded as his top advisers resigned, setting off a further exodus of aides and battering his hopes of a political comeback.
articles.abstract: Newt Gingrich’s campaign imploded as his top advisers resigned, setting off a further exodus of aides and battering his hopes of a political comeback.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Newt Gingrich’s presidential campaign imploded on Thursday as his top advisers banded together and resigned, setting off a further exodus of aides and supporters and battering his hopes of a political comeback.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: Troubled Audit Opinions
articles.snippet: Requiring more detail from auditors could help investors evaluate Sino-Forest Corporation, a company cleared by Ernst & Young but called a fraud by Muddy Waters Research.
articles.abstract: Requiring more detail from auditors could help investors evaluate Sino-Forest Corporation, a company cleared by Ernst & Young but called a fraud by Muddy Waters Research.
articles.lead_paragraph: On one side is an assessment of a company with a clean audit opinion from the Toronto office of Ernst & Young, and with bonds rated just below investment grade by Standard & Poor’s and Moody’s. It has raised billions in capital markets.

articles.headline: Citi Data Theft Points Up a Nagging Problem
articles.snippet: Data breaches like the one against Citigroup have been occurring for years, but the financial industry has failed to prevent them.
articles.abstract: Data breaches like the one against Citigroup have been occurring for years, but the financial industry has failed to prevent them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citigroup’s revelation that hackers stole personal information from more than 200,000 credit card holders makes it one of the largest direct attacks on a major bank.

articles.headline: Companies Spend on Equipment, Not Workers
articles.snippet: As the economy recovers, companies’ capital spending is growing faster than their spending on employees, encouraged by tax breaks and falling prices for equipment.
articles.abstract: As the economy recovers, companies’ capital spending is growing faster than their spending on employees, encouraged by tax breaks and falling prices for equipment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Companies that are looking for a good deal aren’t seeing one in new workers.

articles.headline: Spain Detains 3 in PlayStation Cyberattacks
articles.snippet: The suspects may have been involved in cyberattacks on other corporate and government Web sites, police say.
articles.abstract: The suspects may have been involved in cyberattacks on other corporate and government Web sites, police say.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Spanish police said on Friday that they had apprehended three men suspected of computer hacking in connection with recent attacks on Sony’s PlayStation Network as well as corporate and government Web sites around the world.
articles.byline: By David Jolly and Raphael Minder

articles.headline: Stocks Plunge Amid Fears That Global Economy Is Slowing
articles.snippet: The Dow closed below 12,000 for the first time since March, suggesting that one of the few bright spots for the United States economy may be starting to fade.
articles.abstract: The Dow closed below 12,000 for the first time since March, suggesting that one of the few bright spots for the United States economy may be starting to fade.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors anxious about the outlook for global economic growth sent stocks sharply downward on Friday as the Dow closed below 12,000 for the first time since March.
